description:
Chiroxiphia lanceolata, commonly known as the lance-tailed manakin, is a small passerine bird species belonging to the manakin family, Pipridae. This species is native to the tropical forests of Central and South America, with a distribution ranging from southern Mexico to northwestern Ecuador.

The lance-tailed manakin is a vibrant and distinctive bird, with a striking black and blue plumage. The males exhibit a unique feature, a pair of elongated central tail feathers that resemble lances, giving the species its common name. Females are generally duller in coloration, with greenish-olive upperparts and yellowish-white underparts.

These manakins are known for their elaborate courtship displays, which involve complex acrobatic movements and vocalizations. During the breeding season, males gather in leks, where they perform intricate dances and emit distinctive calls to attract females. The species is predominantly frugivorous, feeding on a variety of berries and small fruits found in the forest canopy.

Chiroxiphia lanceolata plays an important role in the ecosystem as a seed disperser, contributing to the regeneration of the tropical forests it inhabits. This species is considered a species of Least Concern by the IUCN, but some populations may face threats from habitat loss and fragmentation due to deforestation and human activities.
